images.caption: Figure 1:Analysis of token logits ranking patterns across 500 randomly selected images from MSCOCO dataset. Higher ranking indicates higher generation probability.Left:Average token ranking from the last five layers, showing temporal progression across early, mid, and late generation stages.Right:Layer-wise evolution of token rankings averaged across all time steps, demonstrating early-excitation phenomenon.

Figure 2:Token ranking heatmaps for a representative image, demonstrating the evolution of token rankings across model layers (vertical axis) and generation steps (horizontal axis). Darker colors indicate higher ranking. The visualization reveals both gradual visual information loss and early excitation phenomena.

Figure 3:Architectural overview of VISTA. VISTA introduces two complementary mechanisms: VSV extracts and reinforces visual grounding information (VssubscriptV_{s}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) at inference, and SLA leverages early-layer semantic information to guide token generation.Note: While three separate forward passes are shown for illustration purpose, they can be avoided in implementation.

Figure 4:Performance comparison on MMHal-Bench across different question categories: attributes (ATTR), adversarial objects (ADV), comparisons (COMP), counting (COUNT), spatial relations (SPAT), environmental inference (ENV), holistic descriptions (HOL), and others (OTHER). Scores are computed using GPT-4 evaluation protocol.
Figure 5:Cross-stage token ranking comparison between greedy and VISTA on LLAVA-1.5. VISTA effectively promotes the ranking of genuine tokens while depressing hallucination tokens.

Figure 6:Ablation matrices for VSV strength (位\lambdaitalic_位) and SLA mixing ratio (纬\gammaitalic_纬) on Shikra. Brighter color signifies the better performance. Red boxes highlight the parameter combinations we used. F1 score is included to demonstrate the overall generation quality.
